componenttextpreview: That was a big news. And now you all know why we all moved our call to 8:30 in the morning. Good morning, everyone. Sorry about the delay there. Well, obviously, we've got some time to, hopefully, you can all stay with us for the duration of the call. I j
componenttext:
That was a big news. And now you all know why we all moved our call to 8:30 in the morning. Good morning, everyone. Sorry about the delay there. Well, obviously, we've got some time to, hopefully, you can all stay with us for the duration of the call. I just got a text message saying that you can hear us. So thanks, everyone, and good morning. Welcome to Time Warner's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued 2 press releases, one detailing our results for the first quarter, and the other reaffirming our 2016 full year business outlook.
Before we begin, there are 2 items I need to cover.  First, we refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Schedules setting out reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release and trending schedules. These reconciliations are available on our website at www.timewarner.com/investors. Reconciliations of our expected future financial performance are also included in the business outlook release that is available on our website.
Second, today's announcement includes certain forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations. Actual results may vary materially from those expressed or implied by these statements due to various factors. These factors are discussed in detail in Time Warner's SEC filings, including its most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. Time Warner is under no obligation and, in fact, expressly disclaims any obligation to update or alter its forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
I'll now turn the call over to Jeff Bewkes, Time Warner's Chairman and CEO, who'll be followed by Howard Averill, Time Warner's CFO. After their prepared remarks, our divisional CEOs, John Martin, Richard Plepler and Kevin  will join us for a Q&A session. Jeff?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and thanks, everybody, for listening in, staying on the call through our medical report at the beginning. We told you on our last call that we expected 2016 to be another standout year for Time Warner. And in recent years, as you all know, w
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and thanks, everybody, for listening in, staying on the call through our medical report at the beginning. We told you on our last call that we expected 2016 to be another standout year for Time Warner. And in recent years, as you all know, we have been investing aggressively in the very best content while moving quickly to take advantage of new distribution opportunities that are emerging around the world. At the same time, we've maintained our disciplined approach to cost control and capital allocation in order to maximize shareholder returns. And we anticipate that, that combination would allow us to continue to deliver industry-leading performance. That's exactly what you're seeing in our first quarter results. Revenues increased 3% to $7.3 billion and adjusted operating income grew 11% to $2 billion. Adjusted earnings per share grew 25% to $1.49 per share, and we also returned over $1 billion to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends. In addition to strong financial results, we're off to a tremendous start this year from a content perspective. In just the past few weeks, we've had the buzzer-beating final game of March Madness in TBS; CNN's must-watch election coverage; a global hit from Warner Bros. in Batman versus Superman; and the return of HBO's epic series, Game of Thrones. Those are just a few examples of how our investments are translating into great content that deeply engages audiences across platforms and around the world. But there are many more. Let me start with Turner. Once again, Turner had 3 of the top 10 basic cable networks in the U.S., and it continued to make progress on a multiyear transformation of its brands. The first quarter marked the start of TBS' repositioning as for young flesh comedy, with the successful premieres of Full Frontal with Samantha Bee and Separation Anxiety. We follow those up last month with our new hit, The Detour. It's the biggest new comedy on cable this year. The early results are very encouraging with TBS ending the first quarter ranked as the #1 ad-supported cable network in primetime among adults 18-49. And we have a number of additional distinctive shows on this year, including Rex, which will debut next month. The first quarter also marked the start of an acceleration in Turner's domestic affiliate revenue growth, which we've been talking to you about now for some time. That acceleration underscores the strength of the Turner brands and the investments we have been making in them in recent years. One of our most important investments was March Madness. And last March, Turner brought the championship game of the tournament to cable for the very first time. This year's Turner was another great success towards sterling finale and record revenue. Recently, we agreed to build on that success by partnering with CBS to extend our television, digital and marketing rights to the NCAA tournament all the way through 2032. Marquee live sports continue to grow in importance, both the consumers and advertisers. And combined with our extensive multiplatform rights, that gives us a lot of confidence we'll be able to generate a very attractive return on our investment in this unique property. As March Madness wound down, the NBA playoffs are just getting started. The NBA on TNT grew viewership double digits in the first quarter. And with the playoffs underway, we have a great platform for TNT's own drama-focused brand refresh, which starts with Animal Kingdom from Warner Bros. in June. Nowhere Turner's transformation more evidence than CNN, which more than doubled its primetime audience in the first quarter. CNN's ratings benefited from its unrivaled coverage of the U.S. presidential race as well as from its continued success with original series. Those 2 areas overlapped in raise for the White House, which premiered as the most-watched CNN original telecast ever. Home Box Office, I mentioned Game of Thrones already, which grew its opening viewership double digits versus a year ago on a cross-platform basis. But it doesn't stop there. That same weekend, HBO was most to Beyonce's headline grabbing virtual album, lemonade. Also, television premiere of Jurassic World, a world championship boxing match and the return of our 2 lead comedies, feet and Silicon Valley. It was a great example of the range and quality of the content that HBO delivers to its subs. We're just as excited for what's still to come this year at HBO, including the second season of Ballers, that's our new series. It started last year. A new series, Divorce, with Sarah Jessica Parker; and our limited series, The Night Out, which has debuted a Film Festival. At Warner Bros, Batman versus Superman Dawn of Justice, set a record for a March opening weekend, and is already Warner's biggest ever first quarter release. Even better, it's only the opening chapter of an exciting slate of DC Entertainment films that we think will captivate audiences globally for years to come. Next up is Suicide Squad this summer, followed by LEGO Batman, Wonder Woman and Justice league, all in 2017. And as you know, these franchise films are the cornerstone of a strategy that's making DC a growth driver across film, television, digital, games and consumer products. Warner has a lot more on deck, including JK Rowling's return to the big screen this November with Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them. Judging by the huge crowds since the opening last month of the Wizarding World of Harry Potter attraction in Hollywood, there are plenty of fans who were just excited as we are for the next installment of this great franchise. 
In television, Warner has built on its leading position in broadcast with 3 of the top 5 new series this season. That includes not only scripted series like the #1 new show, Blindspot, but also in scripted series like Little Big Shots, which is already been picked up in 2 major international territories. Given a performance of Warner's current shows, with a record 21 renewals ahead of the upfront this year and a strong slate of pilots, Warner's is in a great position to once again lead the industry in broadcast series programming this coming year. And we're also expanding our production for cable and over-the-top services. We have twice the number of new series delivered for next year. So across the company, we are continuing to lead the way of producing groundbreaking content. And to capitalize on the rapid shift to on-demand consumption and broadband delivery of video, we're focused on innovation, both in the type of content we produce and how we get it to consumers. For example, on May 24, Turner is launching . That's our professional competitive gaming league in partnership with WME | IMG. In addition to its telecast on the TBS, eLeague will have a significant digital component and partnership with Twitch. eLeague reflects Turner's commitment to creating and delivering content for multiplatform audience. That commitment is also reflected in Turner's other efforts to grow its presence outside the traditional television ecosystem, particularly in news and sports. CNN finished the quarter as the leading digital news brand in multiplatform video, and Bleacher Report remained the #2 online sports destination. We'll be ramping up investments in both of these properties over the next couple of years to further expand of their leadership positions. 
HBO is also investing in content geared towards digital audiences by bringing on board channels like Bill Simmons and Jon Stewart. Any given Wednesday with Bill Simmons is not to be viewed until next month. But Bill is already making his mark with HBO's first after the drama. Like the Animals, after the thrones is debuting first and HBO NOW and HBO GO. We continue to see significant growth in both users and usage of our digital platforms, and we expect that to continue with our recent expansion of HBO Now to Microsoft's Xbox and to Samsung Smart TVs. We're also expanding the reach of HBO's OTT products internationally. In the first quarter, HBO LAG launched an OTT service in Mexico, and HBO announced plans for OTT launches later this year in Spain, Brazil and Argentina. That's all part of a broader push across the company to develop new services and capabilities. We talked to you previously about Warner's SVOD investments in Asia. In February, Warner Bros. announced the acquisition of Drama Fever to further bolster our OTT capabilities. And just last week, Turner announced its first domestic Xbox service, Film Struck, which will build on the curation expertise of Tcf to targeted enthusiasts of independent, foreign and art house films. At the same time, we're deeply committed to strengthening our core networks and to helping our traditional distribution and network partners improve their products to satisfy consumers' desire for on-demand content. HBO and Turner have been at the forefront of providing multiplatform rights to our partners. And in March, Warners announced  a new deal granting ABC network in-season stacking rights for its new series. So we're making progress on many fronts, both inside and outside the traditional ecosystem. We're seeing the benefits of strong execution of our strategy and how that can continue to deliver superior returns for our shareholders. We've also ramped up our investments and our pace of innovation to meet the high expectations of today's and tomorrow's consumers. And that's why we're so confident about the rest of 2016 and beyond. Thanks for listening, and let me turn it over to Howard Averill.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of our presentation, which is now available on our website. Starting with consolidated results. We're off to a terrific start in 2016 with growth across each of our divisions. And
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of our presentation, which is now available on our website. Starting with consolidated results. We're off to a terrific start in 2016 with growth across each of our divisions. And that resulted in a quarterly record for adjusted operating income, which reached over $2 billion and a 25% increase in adjusted EPS. Total revenues grew 3% and adjusted operating income was up a very healthy 11%, with margins expanding to 100 basis points. And we did that while continuing to grow our investments in programming and marketing at HBO and Turner. That was balanced by lower cost at Warner Bros, mainly due to the timing of our theatrical slate and by our continued company-wide focus on constraining growth and overhead costs. And we're able to once again leverage our positive operating results into even faster growth and adjusted EPS. That was partly due to our ongoing share repurchase program. During the quarter, we bought back $700 million of our shares and combined with our dividend, we've returned close to $1.3 billion to shareholders year-to-date. This morning, we reaffirmed our guidance for 2016 adjusted EPS to be in the range of $5.30 to $5.40. So we're pleased with how we're executing and have significant operating momentum across our businesses, which gives us great confidence in our outlook for the rest of this year and beyond. 
Now turning to the segment highlights. I'll start at Turner. With a benefit from our domestic affiliate renewal cycle and continued strong advertising performance resulting in our best quarter of revenue growth in almost 3 years and record adjusted operating income. Subscription revenues were up a strong 11% in the quarter. And that included a close to 300 basis point headwind from FX. Domestic Subscription revenues grew close to 15% as we benefited from the higher rates we achieved in our recent affiliate agreements. Excluding a 15 percentage point drag from FX, international subscription revenue growth within the high single-digit. While there may be quarter-to-quarter fluctuations due to a variety of factors, domestic sub revenue growth is on track to be in the low-teens for the year, and we expect total subscription revenue growth to the rest of the year to be similar to the first quarter. Advertising was up a solid 5% despite approximately 150 basis points of headwind from FX. Domestic advertising grew in the mid-single digits. That was due to double-digit growth across Time Warner's for both news and sports, including strong growth from the NCAA tournament. International advertising was also healthy in the quarter, up high single digits, excluding a close to 15 percentage point drag from FX. Looking to the second quarter, scatter pricing at our domestic entertainment networks continues to be up well in double digits versus the upfront, and will benefit from the NCAA championship game while FX remains a headwind. As a result, we expect total advertising revenue growth to be in the mid- to high single digits. And with a healthy ad market, continue to grow our industry-leading advance advertising products and momentum in many of our brands, every indication points to a very strong upfront this year. Adjusted operating income increased 10% and margins expanded 100 basis points. And we achieve that even as we continue to invest in programming and marketing as Turner kept all other expenses close to flat in the quarter. Programming expenses increased 4% mainly due to lower investments and sports and election coverage, and marketing costs were up well into the double digits to support TBS and TNT re-brands. So Turner is off to a terrific start in 2016 and is well-positioned for another strong year. And we're confident that the investments were making across our brands will enhance our competitive position and allow us to sustain strong revenue trends and attractive financial results in the future.
Turning now to HBO where we continue to see very strong global demand for the product in the form of both subscriber growth and content licensing. Domestic subscription revenue growth was in the mid-single digits, that included a sequential increase from the benefit from HBO NOW. However, despite year-over-year subscriber growth, we continue to experience headwinds from fewer revenue-generating subscribers at certain MVPDs, which has been partially driven by M&A activity. Over time, we actually see an opportunity to help those partners grow those businesses while accelerating our own revenue growth. Content and other revenue increased 23% in the quarter. That was mainly due to higher international licensing revenues as HBO continues to benefit from its ability to effectively monetize its original content around the world. Across HBO's international networks, including unconsolidated JVs, revenues were up in the double digits, excluding the impact of FX. And international subscriber trends remained strong with healthy growth across all regions, especially LatAm and Europe. Adjusted operating income was up 6% in the quarter, and that was despite a double-digit increase in programming costs as well as continued investments in marketing and technology related to HBO NOW. Increase in programming expenses related to new original programming like Vinyl and Sesame Street as well as programming charges related to series and development. Over HBO if off to a great start to of the year. We're excited about our upcoming programming lineup and we continued investments in the brand and product, we're in a great position to capitalize on the significant global opportunities for premium services.
Moving on to Warner Bros were we posted record first quarter adjusted operating income. On the TV side, we benefited from higher international licensing revenues and that our games business, the continued success of our LEGO and Mortal Kombat franchises helped drive another quarter of double-digit revenue growth. Despite the strong best of Batman versus Superman late in the quarter, total revenues were down modestly due to the difficult theatrical comparisons from last year's release of American Sniper and carryover from the final installment of The Hobbit. Across theatrical and TV, home entertainment revenues were down 12% as last year's quarter benefited from the home video release of the final Hobbit. Despite the difficult comparisons, ESD revenues were still up mid-single digits in the quarter, and we expect our home entertainment trends to improve in the back half of the year as a result of stronger theatrical slate. Adjusted operating income grew close to 30%. In addition to our strong games performance, we also benefited from lower PNA spending as a result of fewer releases this quarter. So Warner Bros. has great momentum, and we're just getting started on the theatrical side with Suicide Squad and Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, leading what should be a very strong lineup for both the remainder of this year and many years to come. Along with our strength in television and video games, that gives us great confidence and Warner's ability to continue delivering attractive growth well into the future. 
Turning to the next slide. Free cash flow totaled over $700 million, which was down from a year ago due to a significant increase in working capital. That is largely related to increased production spend at Warner Bros. as well as the performance of its theatrical product in the fourth quarter of last year and the related impact on accounts receivables. Even so, we still expect very strong cash flow in 2016, driven by strong profit growth and another year of high conversion. Now looking at our balance sheet. We ended the first quarter with $22 billion of net debt, up $500 million compared to the end of 2015. That's primarily a result of our ongoing commitment to direct returns to shareholders, which is a key component of our balanced approach to capital allocation. We ended the quarter just above our target leverage ratio of 2.75x. But we remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and our investment grade credit rating and are on track to return to our target by the end of this year. With that, let's move on to the final slide, which looks at our outlook for 2016. We got off to a strong start in the first quarter, delivering growth across each of our businesses and setting us up for another very good year. That's reflected in our outlook for adjusted EPS of $5.30 to $5.40, which we reaffirm this morning. And based on current rates, that includes an estimated $0.10 headwind from foreign exchange. 
Looking ahead, we still expect growth in adjusted OI to be weighted towards the back half of the year. Specifically in the second quarter, we continue to see positive trends in both advertising and subscription revenue. And global demand for our content remains very strong. But there are several items that we expect to weight on adjusted operating income, including the timing of content licensing revenue, the comparison to strong video games profits at Warner's and last year's quarters, and programming investments at Turner. Despite that, we're on track for another year of very healthy growth and adjusted operating income and solid double-digit earnings growth, extending our history of delivering consistently strong operating and financial performance. And with Turner's revenue trends accelerating, HBO's position to accelerate its subscription revenue growth over the next couple of years, and Warner's and early stages of exciting theatrical slate, we feel we are in great position to continue delivering strong results for many years to come. With that, I'll turn it back to Mike to start the Q&A.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alexia, it's John. Listen, we are proceeding exactly on pace with our internal plan. And so, I mean, if you think about it, Kevin Reilly as the Head of our Entertainment Networks, has been on the job for about 1 year. And it's really his new progr
componenttext:
Thanks, Alexia, it's John. Listen, we are proceeding exactly on pace with our internal plan. And so, I mean, if you think about it, Kevin Reilly as the Head of our Entertainment Networks, has been on the job for about 1 year. And it's really his new programming slate that's just beginning to roll out. We debuted 24 new seasons of owned original series in our domestic networks in the first quarter alone. And we have 20 more slated for the second quarter. And in  this new series, hopefully, give you a small sense for the bold-type quality and engage in programming that you expect from Turner going forward, we are very happy with her critical acclaim and the performance of these new shows are demonstrating across, frankly, all platforms: TV, digital and social. And just to add a little bit more flavor to that, I mean, premiering Angie Tribeca in a very fair with a 25-hour commercial pre-marathon brought about 36% of new young audiences to network. Median age was about 10-year younger about our TBS median. The continued success regular season right, and it ranked #1 on Monday nights across all of cable sitcoms. I think it was Jeff that said who couldn't be more pleased than that with the success of Detour, which recently premiered, and is reaching over 5 million viewers per episode across all of our TBS platforms, and it's ranked #1 of the new comedy releases in adults aged 18-49. Full Frontal with Samantha Bee huge critical and commercial success across all platforms. We're reaching around 3.5 million viewers and we're driving 30 million views on the show's YouTube channel. And that's really just TBS. 
During the first quarter, we have new seasons of Impractical Jokers. And for those we Cartoon Network and the Race for the White House is on CNN. So we're driving, I think, a general improvement in the quality of our original programming across all of our networks. And we've got a lot more to come. And most notably, the TV -- the TNT rebrand will begin later this year. And Jeff mentioned some of the shows that we're really excited about. With respect to the upfront, I just would reiterate the enthusiasm that Howard suggested, which is that given the strong scatter, we're seeing some of our inventory sell for upwards of 30% to 50% higher than last year's upfront levels. And given low cancellations, we think all signs point to frankly the best upfront we would've seen in years. And we think our networks gained at least our fair share of what happens in the upfront. And we think it spells very, very well for just television in general as television is experiencing resurgence in the minds of brand advertisers as we're delivering reach and increasing targeting an audience capabilities. So very, very optimistic.

componenttextpreview: Two separate questions. The first is for John or I guess, John but following up on something what Howard said, which was advanced -- Howard mentioned the advanced advertising array of products. Could you talk a little bit about what you're planning to do
componenttext: Two separate questions. The first is for John or I guess, John but following up on something what Howard said, which was advanced -- Howard mentioned the advanced advertising array of products. Could you talk a little bit about what you're planning to do this year in terms of targeted or advanced advertising? And how different is it for television versus over-the-top I know it's a long one question but on over-the-top, will you participate in Hulu or -- I mean, or not? And then a separate question is for Kevin. Do you think the sale of DreamWorks Animation will spark midsize or other studio consolidation? And if yes, will Warner Bros. participate in consolidation?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica. I'll start of the order of the question. And I appreciate the question. We're spending a lot of work, a lot of time, investment and increasing our capabilities and advertising. And frankly, we're holding ourselves accountable to lead the
componenttext: Thanks, Jessica. I'll start of the order of the question. And I appreciate the question. We're spending a lot of work, a lot of time, investment and increasing our capabilities and advertising. And frankly, we're holding ourselves accountable to lead the charge to modernize TV advertising by combining the unparalleled reach of television with the engaged -- and the engagement of TV with the measurement and targeting capabilities of digital. And we're quickly evolving the advertising industry to simultaneously benefit our advertisers as well as improve our overall consumer experience. And we don't see these goals as being mutually exclusive. Frankly, what we're trying to do is combine the best of both TV and digital, uniting scale and targeting a top-tier -- with top-tier content. As one of the reasons why we are very bullish about the upfront. In terms of our own new products, we've discussed before that we have built on the Turner which is the central depository of all of our consumer information. And that's helping us launch new innovative products that focus on analytics, targeting on ROIs. So just the products we got individual products called targeting now, Audience Now, ROI Now, Provable ROI. All that means it's going to be targeting audience-based selling coupled with our data cloud and client insights. And I think they are going to be increasing opportunities overtime and that's going to be a major, major focus in our upfronts. And then I think you asked specifically with respect to OTT. I think the opportunities to develop advanced targeting capabilities in OTT are absolutely there. They're available. That is assuming that the OTT offering is in fact ad-supported which is our first domestic offering is going to be non-ad-supported, which is consistent return of Turner Classic Movies. So I think the targeting opportunities will only grow over time, and we're still very, very -- in the very early stages. So we believe that TV advertising has to evolve but it's going to remain the most effective option for brand advertisers to convey the message at scale. And that's why we expect the resurgence in TV advertising beginning at this year's upfront.

componenttextpreview: I see. Okay. Let me start. And John, you might want to fill in. Just maybe, we want our networks and every one of these packets. I think we ought to include that in the larger view of how the industry is evolving. Any if you think about subscription VOD,
componenttext: I see. Okay. Let me start. And John, you might want to fill in. Just maybe, we want our networks and every one of these packets. I think we ought to include that in the larger view of how the industry is evolving. Any if you think about subscription VOD, it's been an opportunity that started with the first Xbox service, which is called HBO, a long time ago. And while we're retching happen and I think it probably start with HBO ago is consumers want to expect there going to demand SVOD access to all their favorite networks, all their favorite shows. And what we've been seeing as an evolution is that on-demand functionality and better guys are sprouting up first in HBO, then in some of the broadband-delivered services and increasingly, you're seeing more full on-demand offerings of current exhibition networks and better interfaces and recommendation engines in places like Comcast, Verizon, . And for us, with our networks, whether it's the Turner networks or the HBO networks, we've long said that moved like our networks and their program, including the debuts of current 4 season exhibitions like what John is talking about and what Rich has been doing for years at HBO. We want them to be on-demand, and we would like to see most of our networks, whichever exhibition first-run or syndication to be on-demand. And we're basically in an enviable position networks, Turner and HBO, are among the most desired networks for consumers, and, therefore, to be included in all these packages. So you'll hear, I think increasingly, of different packages with different network offerings that consumers can choose between at different price points available from existing cable, satellite and telco distributors, increasingly from new virtual distributors, whether it be Hulu, whether it's Amazon, Apple. Whoever comes in and crates packages for consumers. So I think what you're seeing is a very vibrant rebirth of the strength of TV networks and TV programming across all of these distribution platforms. And because of our -- we've always taken the position being the first to launch VOD that we think more of it is better for consumers. And therefore, we're going to try to be available in all the packages consumers are interested in.

componenttext: And as it relates to DreamWorks Animation transaction, I don't think you're going to see significantly more consolidation. Whether it's networks or programming, we're seeing our stuff going into all of these new platforms. And it's raising the value not only of our content if you covet so my show but also power networks.

componenttextpreview: Two Turner-related questions. First on the affiliate growth. Several of your peers the impact from the distributor consideration and some rate resets dragging on their growth. Obviously, you're putting up great growth right now. Do you expect to have any
componenttext: Two Turner-related questions. First on the affiliate growth. Several of your peers the impact from the distributor consideration and some rate resets dragging on their growth. Obviously, you're putting up great growth right now. Do you expect to have any impact in the future from consolidation. Is any impact consolidation are already in your results or perhaps the way you're structured you won't be impacted by that? And then my second question is on eLeague. Specifically most strategies we see is taking linear content and finding new digital avenues. This is a case were taken digitally and you bring it to TV. Could you just talk a little bit about what you think that's right strategy, what your hopes are for that product?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. With respect to our affiliates, the forecast for that is that we provided for this year and next year, where we expect domestic subscriber revenues to be in the low-teens. I think it's fair to say that, that considers the current environment, the nu
componenttext: Sure. With respect to our affiliates, the forecast for that is that we provided for this year and next year, where we expect domestic subscriber revenues to be in the low-teens. I think it's fair to say that, that considers the current environment, the number of distributors and what's happening in the marketplace. And when you have a highly concentrated portfolio of must-have networks which we do, where we've got 85% of our affiliate revenues in 4 networks, I think it's a really advantageous place to be. So I think, I'll leave it at that because obviously, we're not going to specifically comment on any particular consolidation. And then with respect to eLeague, look, this is one of the innovations with respect to content that I think we're particularly excited about and proud of. And it's really -- it's not necessarily by design that we're looking to take digitals content and move it to the TV. It's more just really trying to position the company to be where consumers are. And looking at secular growth areas and in looking at areas where particularly young people are spending tremendous amounts of time, you obviously have to pay attention to the gaming industry but this whole notion of very significant population of individuals were really excited to sit and watch professional gamers and some of the best gamers in the world, that's already happening. It's happening globally. And in some countries, it represents some of the highest levels of consumption of video content. So in some respects, having eLeague be aired on TBS is somewhat of an experiment. I think we're going to learn a lot this year. And I look forward to hopefully, building a big franchise and a big asset along with our partners on both TV and digital platforms.

componenttext: In terms of how we aggregate our programming positions, I think as a look at the network right now, you see kind of a textbook example of how we break up different genres. Documentaries, miniseries, half hours, hours, original films, sports programming. And as I've said before, division of programming is to build as many addicts as we can out there in the consumer base and different people love different things. So you have huge Silicon Valley past, huge Oliver Spence, huge sports fans. So we'll like the way we are big enough our choices. And a lot of this, of course,'s informative talent it comes through the door. Somebody comes in with a renowned idea for an additional half hour, we're not going to say no to wait because we have a certain number that we think is a seeming. That's not how we make choices. Terms of HBO NOW, what we have done is we bought in our programming with decisions like Johnston words and VICE News. I think Bill Simmons will work across all platforms. So again, that opportunities to be not constrained by schedule is opening up a lot of creativity in the part of our talent were coming in literally every week with new ideas. So you're going to see more and more of that going forward. So listen, would like our mix. We think if you look at just the Emmy nominations and the Emmy wins for last year, I think that the thing that was most rewarding for us was that there were across all categories. A wide range of categories. And I think that what makes our programming mix so special.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's important to look, basically, to be aggregate the performance in the cable telco satellite world. So you do have affiliates, cable affiliates who are growing subs in penetration. And the reason basically is there offering very effective
componenttext: Yes. I think it's important to look, basically, to be aggregate the performance in the cable telco satellite world. So you do have affiliates, cable affiliates who are growing subs in penetration. And the reason basically is there offering very effective packages of VOD. They've got various packages of different network bundles for consumer. They've got that guide interfaces. So you have a fairly large disparity in performance between distributors. And I think if you look at the high-performance we see where the future can go. And the fact that you now have more VOD offerings in different packages and in price plants, is basically, I think -- we've seen it happen. It's going to increase penetration. The consumers are going to find more packages that suit what they want. And in most cases, that'll be the biggest and largest packages for the big networks. But not in all cases. So I think you're going to see -- and remember, with extent you have some marketing of VOD products and broadband delivery with good navigation. It basically increases consumer -- consumer recognition for powerful networks like CNN, TNT, HBO. All of that has kind of a national effect of increasing the presence of TV networks because all age groups increasingly now are finding the favorite programs offered the way they want them. They find a way to the networks if we sell them in the right distribution offering.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I say one thing. There's too many networks in the United States. And we've been saying for years that there's going to be a rationalization of those networks. So as you think about subscription trends going forward, I think they were going to be incre
componenttext: Can I say one thing. There's too many networks in the United States. And we've been saying for years that there's going to be a rationalization of those networks. So as you think about subscription trends going forward, I think they were going to be increasingly differentiated subscription trends. Meaning that marginal or lesser value networks are going to find it very difficult to keep their footing and keep pace with the best networks. And I think further to what Jeff has said, as affiliates, whether they're traditional or nontraditional affiliates, put up packages are smaller packages of better networks at lower economic price points, we're going to be able to attract back households into the multichannel ecosystem that have, finally, moved away because they don't see the value of bundles. That would be good for us.

componenttext: Well, look, as we saw in the Nordics, churn was a bit validated initially. But as you would expect, the churn has been coming down as our subscriber base is aging. I think as we continue to drive churn down over time, we improve the service, we improve our UI and UX. We roll out more of the programming that I spoke of earlier. I think we learn and we are learning how to better serve our customer and continue to affect a decline in churn.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your question about how we're gauging a successful show. Look, it's largely about whether we think something is elevating the brand. And that's obviously a subjective judgment that we make all the time. It's not so much about rating. It's whether or no
componenttext: On your question about how we're gauging a successful show. Look, it's largely about whether we think something is elevating the brand. And that's obviously a subjective judgment that we make all the time. It's not so much about rating. It's whether or not it's serving what we think is its  design purpose to affect resonance a particular part of our consumer base. So as I said earlier, it's all about developing the kind of engagement with our subscriber. Some people are going to look at real sports with the same degree of passion other people look at or John Oliver. Some people are going to look deep with the same passion that other people will look at Silicon Valley. So this is a very subjective determination. We've been doing it for a long time. We think we have pretty good instincts about how to build a large variety in our slate, which appeals to a huge part of our consumer base. There's no exact science to it. And obviously critical acclaim plays a role. But we have a very good collective instinct inside the company when we think something is resonating with a particular part of our audience. And we give our creative teams an opportunity to stay with it and develop story and continue to build the show as we've shown over many years.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. This is John. With respect -- for anybody who is unaware because you made reference to True TV and ad modes. We announced a number of months ago, our intention that beginning in the fourth quarter of this year, we're going to essentially take the
componenttext: Thanks. This is John. With respect -- for anybody who is unaware because you made reference to True TV and ad modes. We announced a number of months ago, our intention that beginning in the fourth quarter of this year, we're going to essentially take the number of minutes per hour on True TV dedicated to advertising. We're going to essentially cut it in half. And that, again, is consistent with our desire to evolve the industry that's going to simultaneously benefit our advertisers and improve the overall consumer experience. I'll tell you that we're not doing it to lose money. So we fully intend to provide increased value per inventory unit that we sell. And now it's up to us to demonstrate that. But we are actively going to be moving beyond the 32nd spot of business to create innovative new ad products for our advertisers and marketers. And we made a number of announcements, a number of months ago at CVS, including data plus with longer form brand ad breaks and launchpad, which is a social tool and Courageous, which is our own in-house ability to develop branded content in the form of advertising. Again, I would say we're going to learn a lot. But we absolutely believe that this experiment is not going to result in us taking a step back.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just to see if I could follow up on that. John, how are you thinking about the ad loads on the other networks? I mean do you first do this with True TV? See what to learned? And then start thinking about a larger networks or is there anything that y
componenttext: I was just to see if I could follow up on that. John, how are you thinking about the ad loads on the other networks? I mean do you first do this with True TV? See what to learned? And then start thinking about a larger networks or is there anything that you're doing now in terms of that load reductions on TBS and TNT?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not doing anything material today. And what one of the reasons why we are starting with this commitment on true TV is, obviously, it's a network where we have less advertising exposure than some of our lower larger networks like TBS and TNT. Having
componenttext: We're not doing anything material today. And what one of the reasons why we are starting with this commitment on true TV is, obviously, it's a network where we have less advertising exposure than some of our lower larger networks like TBS and TNT. Having said that, the type of approach and ideology that we're -- we have with True TV, which we think will succeed, we're already beginning to plan for on some of our other networks. And I believe it was Kevin Reilly of TCA that mentioned that on some of our new original programming, we're actually going to be making more minutes of content with the expectation that on a number of those new original scripted series, we'll probably be running fewer ad commercial breaks. So this is going to be an evolution. But it's something that we're planning now for what's going to take place in the future.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to thank everyone for hanging in through our medical section. And I hope you can all see how we are so excited about not only our prospects for the business this year but in the years out beyond that. We think the company is very well-position
componenttext: I just want to thank everyone for hanging in through our medical section. And I hope you can all see how we are so excited about not only our prospects for the business this year but in the years out beyond that. We think the company is very well-positioned and the evolution of the networks as Warner going global is proceeding as well as I could have hoped. And I'm also seeing a lot of encouragement and industry developments. I think the industry around the world is finally starting to catch up to the innovation speed necessary to take this huge value that's resonant in all the network offerings, not just ours, and bring it to consumers in a way that consumers increasingly want. So we're quite encouraged about the environment that we're operating in and particularly our strength relative to the others.

It's [indiscernible]. So sorry about the delay there. Well, obviously, we've got some time, so hopefully, you can all stay with us for the duration of the call. I just got a text message saying that you can hear us. So thanks, everyone, and good morning. Welcome to Time Warner's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued 2 press releases, one detailing our results for the first quarter; and the other reaffirming our 2016 full year business outlook.
Before we begin, there are 2 items I need to cover. First, we refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Schedules setting out reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release and trending schedules. These reconciliations are available on our website at www.timewarner.com/investors. Reconciliations of our expected future financial performance are also included in the business outlook release that is available on our website.
Second, today's announcement includes certain forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations. Actual results may vary materially from those expressed or implied by these statements due to various factors. These factors are discussed in detail in Time Warner's SEC filings, including its most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. Time Warner is under no obligation and, in fact, expressly disclaims any obligation to update or alter its forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
I'll now turn the call over to Jeff Bewkes, Time Warner's Chairman and CEO, who'll be followed by Howard Averill, Time Warner's CFO. After their prepared remarks, our divisional CEOs, John Martin, Richard Plepler and Kevin Tsujihara will join us for a Q&A session.
Jeff?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and thanks, everybody, for listening in, staying on the call through our medical report at the beginning. We told you on our last call that we expected 2016 to be another standout year for Time Warner. And in recent years, as you all know, w
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and thanks, everybody, for listening in, staying on the call through our medical report at the beginning. We told you on our last call that we expected 2016 to be another standout year for Time Warner. And in recent years, as you all know, we have been investing aggressively in the very best content while moving quickly to take advantage of new distribution opportunities that are emerging around the world. At the same time, we've maintained our disciplined approach to cost control and capital allocation in order to maximize shareholder returns. And we anticipate that, that combination would allow us to continue to deliver industry-leading performance.
That's exactly what you're seeing in our first quarter results. Revenues increased 3% to $7.3 billion and adjusted operating income grew 11% to $2 billion. Adjusted earnings per share grew 25% to $1.49 per share, and we also returned over $1 billion to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends.
In addition to strong financial results, we're off to a tremendous start this year from a content perspective. In just the past few weeks, we've had the buzzer-beating final game of March Madness on TBS; CNN's must-watch election coverage; a global hit from Warner Bros. in Batman v Superman; and the return of HBO's epic series, Game of Thrones. Those are just a few examples of how our investments are translating into great content that deeply engages audiences across platforms and around the world. But there are many more. Let me start with Turner.
Once again, Turner had 3 of the top 10 basic cable networks in the U.S., and it continued to make progress on a multiyear transformation of its brands. The first quarter marked the start of TBS's repositioning as the place for young, fresh comedy with the successful premieres of Angie Tribeca, Full Frontal with Samantha Bee and Separation Anxiety. We followed those up last month with our new hit, The Detour. It's the biggest new comedy on cable this year. The early results are very encouraging with TBS ending the first quarter ranked as the #1 ad-supported cable network in prime time among adults 18 to 49. And we have a number of additional distinctive shows on tap this year, including Rex Wrecked, which will debut next month.
The first quarter also marked the start of an acceleration in Turner's domestic affiliate revenue growth, which we've been talking to you about now for some time. That acceleration underscores the strength of the Turner brands and the investments we have been making in them in recent years. One of our most important investments was March Madness. And last March, Turner brought the championship game of the tournament to cable for the very first time. This year's tournament was another great success towards in both the sterling finale and record revenue. Recently, we agreed to build on that success by partnering with CBS to extend our television, digital and marketing rights to the NCAA tournament all the way through 2032. Marquee live sports continue to grow in importance, both to consumers and advertisers. And combined with our extensive multi-platform rights, that gives us a lot of confidence we'll be able to generate a very attractive return on our investment in this unique property.
As March Madness wound down, the NBA playoffs were just getting started. The NBA on TNT grew viewership double digits in the first quarter. And with the playoffs underway, we have a great platform for TNT's own drama-focused brand refresh, which starts with Animal Kingdom from Warner Bros. in June. Nowhere has Turner's transformation more evident than at CNN, which more than doubled its prime time audience in the first quarter. CNN's ratings benefited from its unrivaled coverage of the U.S. presidential race as well as from its continued success with original series. Those 2 areas overlapped in Race for the White House, which premiered as the most-watched CNN original telecast ever.
Over at Home Box Office, I mentioned Game of Thrones already, which grew its opening viewership double digits versus a year ago on a cross-platform basis. But it doesn't stop there. That same weekend, HBO was host to Beyonc's headline-grabbing visual album, Lemonade; also, the television premiere of Jurassic World; a world championship boxing match; and the return of our 2 hit comedies, Veep and Silicon Valley. It's -- it was a great example of the range and quality of the content that HBO delivers to its subs. We're just as excited for what's still to come this year at HBO, including the second season of Ballers, that's our new series, started last year; a new series, Divorce, with Sarah Jessica Parker; and our limited series, THE NIGHT OF, which just previewed to a tremendous reception at the Tribeca Film Festival.
At Warner Bros., Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice set a record for a March opening weekend, and it's already Warner's biggest-ever first quarter release. Even better, it's only the opening chapter of an exciting slate of DC Entertainment films that we think will captivate audiences globally for years to come. Next up is Suicide Squad this summer, followed by LEGO Batman, Wonder Woman and Justice League, all in 2017. And as you know, these franchise films are the cornerstone of a strategy that's making DC a growth driver across film, television, digital, games and consumer products. Warner's has a lot more on deck, including J.K. Rowling's return to the big screen this November with Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them. Judging by the huge crowd since the opening last month of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter attraction in Hollywood, there are plenty of fans who are just excited as we are for the next installment of this great franchise.
In television, Warner's has built on its leading position in broadcast with 3 of the top 5 new series this season. That includes not only scripted series like the #1 new show, Blindspot, but also unscripted series like Little Big Shots, which has already been picked up in 2 major international territories. Given the performance of Warner's current shows with a record 21 renewals ahead of the Upfront this year and a strong slate of pilots, Warner's is in a great position to once again lead the industry in broadcast series programming this coming season. And we're also expanding our production for cable and over-the-top services. We have twice the number of new series orders for next season. So across the company, we're continuing to lead the way of producing groundbreaking content.
And to capitalize on the rapid shift to on-demand consumption and broadband delivery of video, we're focused on innovation, both in the type of content we produce and how we get it to consumers. For example, on May 24, Turner is launching ELEAGUE, that's our professional competitive gaming league, in partnership with WME | IMG. In addition to its telecast on the TBS, ELEAGUE will have a significant digital component and partnership with Twitch. ELEAGUE reflects Turner's commitment to creating and delivering content for multi-platform audiences. That commitment is also reflected in Turner's other efforts to grow its presence outside the traditional television ecosystem, particularly in news and sports. CNN finished the quarter as the leading digital news brand in multi-platform video, and Bleacher Report remained the #2 online sports destination. We'll be ramping up investments in both of these properties over the next couple of years to further expand on their leadership positions.
HBO is also investing in content geared toward digital audiences by bringing onboard talent like Bill Simmons and Jon Stewart. Any Given Wednesday with Bill Simmons does not debut until next month, but Bill's already making his mark with HBO's first aftershow, After the Thrones. Like Animals, After the Thrones is debuting first and HBO NOW and HBO GO. We continue to see significant growth in both users and usage of our digital platforms, and we expect that to continue with our recent expansion of HBO NOW to Microsoft's Xbox and to Samsung Smart TVs.
We're also expanding the reach of HBO's OTT products internationally. In the first quarter, HBO LAG launched an OTT service in Mexico, and HBO announced plans for OTT launches later this year in Spain, Brazil and Argentina. That's all part of a broader push across the company to develop new services and capabilities. We talked to you previously about Warner's SVOD investments in Asia. In February, Warner Bros. announced the acquisition of DramaFever to further bolster our OTT capabilities. And just last week, Turner announced its first domestic SVOD service, FilmStruck, which will build on the curation expertise of TCM to targeted enthusiasts of independent, foreign and art house films. At the same time, we're deeply committed to strengthening our core networks and to helping our traditional distribution and network partners improve their products to satisfy consumers' desire for on-demand content. HBO and Turner have been at the forefront of providing on-demand and multi-platform rights to our partners. And in March, Warner's announced a new deal granting ABC network in-season stacking rights for its new series.
So we're making progress on many fronts, both inside and outside the traditional ecosystem. We're seeing the benefits of strong execution of our strategy and how that can continue to deliver superior returns for our shareholders. We've also ramped up our investments and our pace of innovation to meet the high expectations of today's and tomorrow's consumers. And that's why we're so confident about the rest of 2016 and beyond.
Thanks for listening, and let me turn it over to Howard Averill.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of our presentation, which is now available on our website. Starting with consolidated results. We're off to a terrific start in 2016 with growth across each of our divisions, a
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of our presentation, which is now available on our website. Starting with consolidated results. We're off to a terrific start in 2016 with growth across each of our divisions, and that resulted in a quarterly record for adjusted operating income, which reached over $2 billion and a 25% increase in adjusted EPS. Total revenues grew 3%, and adjusted operating income was up a very healthy 11% with margins expanding 200 basis points. And we did that while continuing to grow our investments in programming and marketing at HBO and Turner. That was balanced by lower cost at Warner Bros., mainly due to the timing of our theatrical slate and by our continued company-wide focus on constraining growth and overhead costs. And we're able to once again leverage our positive operating results into even faster growth and adjusted EPS. That was partly due to our ongoing share repurchase program. During the quarter, we bought back $700 million of our shares. And combined with our dividend, we've returned close to $1.3 billion to shareholders year-to-date. This morning, we reaffirmed our guidance for 2016 adjusted EPS to be in the range of $5.30 to $5.40. So we're pleased with how we're executing and have significant operating momentum across our businesses, which gives us great confidence in our outlook for the rest of this year and beyond.
Now turning to the segment highlights. I'll start at Turner with the benefit from our domestic affiliate renewal cycle and continued strong advertising performance resulting in our best quarter of revenue growth in almost 3 years and record adjusted operating income. Subscription revenues were up a strong 11% in the quarter, and that included a close to 300 basis point headwind from FX. Domestic subscription revenues grew close to 15% as we benefited from the higher rates we achieved in our recent affiliate agreements. Excluding a 15 percentage point drag from FX, international subscription revenue growth was in the high single digits. While there may be quarter-to-quarter fluctuations due to a variety of factors, domestic sub revenue growth is on track to be in the low teens for the year, and we expect total subscription revenue growth through the rest of the year to be similar to the first quarter.
Advertising was up a solid 5% despite approximately 150 basis points of headwind from FX. Domestic advertising grew in the mid-single digits. That was due to double-digit growth across Turner's linear and digital properties for both news and sports, including strong growth from the NCAA tournament. International advertising was also healthy in the quarter, up high single digits, excluding a close to 15 percentage point drag from FX.
Looking to the second quarter, scatter pricing at our domestic entertainment networks continues to be up well in double digits versus the Upfront and will benefit from the NCAA championship game while FX remains a headwind. As a result, we expect total advertising revenue growth to be in the mid to high single digits. And with a healthy ad market, continued rollout of our industry-leading advance advertising products and momentum at many of our brands, every indication points to a very strong Upfront this year.
Adjusted operating income increased 10%, and margins expanded 100 basis points. And we achieved that even as we continue to invest in programming and marketing as Turner kept all other expenses close to flat in the quarter. Programming expenses increased 4% mainly due to our investments in sports and election coverage, and marketing costs were up well into the double digits to support the TBS and TNT rebrands. So Turner is off to a terrific start in 2016 and is well positioned for another strong year. And we're confident the investments we are making across our brands will enhance our competitive position and allow us to sustain strong revenue trends and attractive financial results in the future.
Turning now to HBO where we continue to see very strong global demand for the product in the form of both subscriber growth and content licensing. Domestic subscription revenue growth was in the mid-single digits, and that included a sequential increase on the benefit from HBO NOW. However, despite year-over-year subscriber growth, we continue to experience headwinds from fewer revenue-generating subscribers at certain MVPDs, which has been partially driven by M&A activity. Over time, we actually see an opportunity to help those partners grow their businesses while accelerating our own revenue growth.
Content and other revenue increased 23% in the quarter. That was mainly due to higher international licensing revenues as HBO continues to benefit from its ability to effectively monetize its original content around the world. Across HBO's international networks, including unconsolidated JVs, revenues were up in the double digits, excluding the impact of FX, and international subscriber trends remained strong with healthy growth across all regions, especially LatAm and Europe.
Adjusted operating income was up 6% in the quarter, and that was despite a double-digit increase in programming costs as well as continued investments in marketing and technology related to HBO NOW. The increase in programming expense is related to new original programming like Vinyl and Sesame Street as well as programming charges related to series and development. Overall, HBO is off to a great start to the year. We're excited about our upcoming programming lineup. And with continued investments in the brand and product, we're in a great position to capitalize on the significant global opportunities for premium services.
Moving on to Warner Bros. where we posted record first quarter adjusted operating income. On the TV side, we benefited from higher international licensing revenues. And at our games business, the continued success of our LEGO and Mortal Kombat franchises helped drive another quarter of double-digit revenue growth. Despite the strong box office opening of Batman v Superman late in the quarter, total revenues were down modestly due to the difficult theatrical comparisons from last year's release of American Sniper and carryover from the final installment of The Hobbit. Across theatrical and TV, home entertainment revenues were down 12% as last year's quarter benefited from the home video release of the final Hobbit. So despite the difficult comparisons, EST revenues were still up mid-single digits in the quarter, and we expect our home entertainment trends to improve in the back half of the year as a result of stronger theatrical slate.
Adjusted operating income grew close to 30%. In addition to our strong games performance, we also benefited from lower P&A spending as a result of fewer releases this quarter. So Warner Bros. has great momentum, and we're just getting started on the theatrical side with Suicide Squad and Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, leading what should be a very strong lineup for both the remainder of this year and many years to come. Along with our strength in television and video games, that gives us great confidence in Warner's ability to continue delivering attractive growth well into the future.
Turning to the next slide. Free cash flow totaled over $700 million, which was down from a year ago due to a significant increase in working capital. That was largely related to increased production spend at Warner Bros. as well as the performance of its theatrical product in the fourth quarter of last year and the related impact on accounts receivables. Even so, we still expect very strong cash flow in 2016 driven by strong profit growth and another year of high conversion.
Now looking at our balance sheet. We ended the first quarter with $22 billion of net debt, up $500 million compared to the end of 2015. That's primarily a result of our ongoing commitment to direct returns to shareholders, which is a key component of our balanced approach to capital allocation. We ended the quarter just above our target leverage ratio of 2.75x. But we remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and our investment-grade credit rating and are on track to return to our target by the end of this year.
With that, let's move on to the final slide, which looks at our outlook for 2016. We got off to a strong start in the first quarter, delivering growth across each of our businesses and setting us up for another very good year. That's reflected in our outlook for adjusted EPS of $5.30 to $5.40, which we reaffirmed this morning. And based on current rates, that includes an estimated $0.10 headwind from foreign exchange.
Looking ahead, we still expect growth in adjusted OI to be weighted towards the back half of the year. Specifically in the second quarter, we continue to see positive trends in both advertising and subscription revenue, and global demand for our content remains very strong. But there are several items that we expect to weigh on adjusted operating income, including the timing of content licensing revenue, the comparison to strong video games profits at Warner's in last year's quarters and programming investments at Turner. Despite that, we're on track for another year of very healthy growth in adjusted operating income and solid double-digit earnings growth, extending our history of delivering consistently strong operating and financial performance. And with Turner's revenue trends accelerating, HBO positioned to accelerate its subscription revenue growth over the next couple of years and Warner's in the early stages of an exciting theatrical slate, we feel we're in great position to continue delivering strong results for many years to come.
With that, I'll turn it back to Mike to start the Q&A.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have one for Kevin and one for Richard. I'll hold off my St. Jude questions for later. Kevin, as Jeff Bewkes said, ABC and Warner's announced the deal in March that gives ABC in-season stacking rights to all new series. So wondering, could you talk abou
componenttext: I have one for Kevin and one for Richard. I'll hold off my St. Jude questions for later. Kevin, as Jeff Bewkes said, ABC and Warner's announced the deal in March that gives ABC in-season stacking rights to all new series. So wondering, could you talk about whether or not that's going to be a standard do you think for other networks going forward? And then, how do your back-end economics are affected by giving people more early window rights? What does that mean for your SVOD windows and maybe the second and third windows after that?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't think it impacts the back end value of the rights. We've been -- we've given Turner stacking rights. We've sold stacking rights to Fox last year on Lucifer, and we feel really good about the deal we get with ABC. I can't speak for the rest of the
componenttext: We don't think it impacts the back end value of the rights. We've been -- we've given Turner stacking rights. We've sold stacking rights to Fox last year on Lucifer, and we feel really good about the deal we get with ABC. I can't speak for the rest of the industry. But I know that we are having a number of conversations with all the networks about stacking rights and think that it's certainly a good thing for consumers.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: And will you sell -- will you only sell rights, going forward, with stacking rights included? Is that the kind of your template? Or are you flexible based on what the networks need?

componenttext: Okay. And then Richard, we have a lot of questions about the timing of your next round of affiliate fee negotiations. headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, look, as we've said before, March percentage rev deals are up to the next couple of years; some of them, toward the end of this year. We think that's a huge opportunity for us because some of the poor-performing affiliates are being acquired by s
componenttext: Michael, look, as we've said before, March percentage rev deals are up to the next couple of years; some of them, toward the end of this year. We think that's a huge opportunity for us because some of the poor-performing affiliates are being acquired by some of the higher-performing affiliates. And obviously, we see that as a big opportunity going forward for revenue growth. And some of the better-performing affiliates, those deals will come up in the next year or so, and we see an opportunity to monetize some of those subs as well. So you can look for the next 18 months to 2 years where the vast preponderance of our affiliate fees [ph].

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: My questions are on Turner. You've increased your investments in some of the original program in the Turner. You highlighted in your opening comments with some of these premieres coming out recently. How are you trending, I guess, on this front? How have they been doing versus your plan, and I guess any overall commentary in the Upfront?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alexia, it's John. Listen, I think we're -- we are proceeding exactly on pace with our internal plan. And so I mean, if you think about it, Kevin Reilly as the Head of our Entertainment Networks has been on the job for about a year. And it's reall
componenttext: Thanks, Alexia, it's John. Listen, I think we're -- we are proceeding exactly on pace with our internal plan. And so I mean, if you think about it, Kevin Reilly as the Head of our Entertainment Networks has been on the job for about a year. And it's really his new programming slate that's just beginning to roll out. We debut 24 new seasons of owned original series on our domestic networks in the first quarter alone, and we have 20 more slated for the second quarter. And these new series, hopefully, give you a small sense for the bold-type quality and engaging programming that you can expect from Turner going forward, and we're very happy with the critical acclaim and the performance of these new shows are demonstrating across, frankly, all platforms: TV, digital and social. And just to add a little bit more flavor to that, I mean, premiering Angie Tribeca in a very new and unique way with a 25-hour commercial-free marathon brought about 36% new young audiences to network. Median age was about 10 years younger that our TBS median. And it continued its success on its regular season run, and it ranked #1 on Monday nights across all of cable sitcoms. I think it was Jeff that said who couldn't be more pleased than with the success of Detour, which recently premiered, and is reaching over 5 million viewers per episode across all of our TBS platforms, and it's ranked #1 of the new comedy releases in adults 18 to 49. Full Frontal with Samantha Bee, huge critical and commercial success across all platforms. We're reaching around 3.5 million viewers, and we're driving 30 million views on the show's YouTube channel. And that's really just TBS. During the first quarter, we have new seasons of Impractical Jokers. And for those who can't actually [ph] DV, We Bare Bears and Steven Universe on Cartoon Network, and the Race for the White House from the 80s on CNN. So we're driving, I think, a general improvement in the quality of our original programming across all of our networks, and we've got a lot more to come. And most notably, the TV -- the TNT rebrand will begin later this year. And Jeff mentioned some of the shows that we're really excited about. With respect to the Upfront, I just would reiterate the enthusiasm that Howard suggested, which is that given the strong scatter, we're seeing some of our inventory sell for upwards of 30% to 50% higher than last year's Upfront levels. And given low cancellations, we think all signs point to, frankly, the best Upfront we would've seen in years. And we think our networks stand to gain at least our fair share of what happens in the Upfront. And we think it spells very, very well for just television in general as television is experiencing resurgence in the minds of brand advertisers as we're delivering reach and increasing targeting and audience capabilities. So very, very optimistic.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Richard. Look, I think, as I said earlier, huge opportunity for us going forward because in the higher performing affiliates that are acquiring the weaker affiliates, the blended penetration is below industry average. That gives us an opportunity wit
componenttext: It's Richard. Look, I think, as I said earlier, huge opportunity for us going forward because in the higher performing affiliates that are acquiring the weaker affiliates, the blended penetration is below industry average. That gives us an opportunity with our partners to grow together up to the better performing affiliates penetration levels and beyond. So we see this as an opportunity for them. And we see this as an opportunity for us. And listen, all negotiations are difficult, but we think this is going to be a win-win.
