headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes. We feel great about the long-term growth of Warner Bros., and we continue to feel that way. We're going to continue to grow, as we said in the past, our leading television business. We have 21 shows, as Jeff mentioned earlier, coming back. And
componenttext: Right. Yes. We feel great about the long-term growth of Warner Bros., and we continue to feel that way. We're going to continue to grow, as we said in the past, our leading television business. We have 21 shows, as Jeff mentioned earlier, coming back. And we -- there's still 3 or 4 more shows that we might also get picked up. And we feel great about our pilots so far. We're going to continue to build on the actual slate. We love the pipeline. And it's going to be -- the foundation is going to be the franchises that we've talked about, DC, Fantastic Beasts and LEGO. And we're going to continue to focus on margins. We think that there's -- we've done a very good job in reducing costs. But we think there's still work to do. So we feel really good about the long-term growth of Warner Bros.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 separate questions. The first is for John or -- I guess John, but following up on something Howard said, which was advanced -- Howard mentioned the advanced advertising array of products. Could you talk a little bit about what you're planning to
componenttext: I have 2 separate questions. The first is for John or -- I guess John, but following up on something Howard said, which was advanced -- Howard mentioned the advanced advertising array of products. Could you talk a little bit about what you're planning to do this year in terms of targeted or advanced advertising? And how different is it for television versus over-the-top? And on -- I know this is a long one question, but on over-the-top, will you participate in Hulu or -- I mean, or not? And then a separate -- second question is for Kevin. Do you think the sale of DreamWorks Animation will spark midsize or other studio consolidation? And if yes, will Warner Bros. participate in consolidation?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica. So I'll start just taking it in the order that you asked the questions. So listen, we -- and I appreciate the question, we're spending a lot of work, a lot of time, investment in increasing our capabilities in advertising. And frankly, we
componenttext: Thanks, Jessica. So I'll start just taking it in the order that you asked the questions. So listen, we -- and I appreciate the question, we're spending a lot of work, a lot of time, investment in increasing our capabilities in advertising. And frankly, we're holding ourselves accountable to lead the charge to modernize TV advertising by combining the unparalleled reach of television with the engaged -- and the engagement of TV with the measurement and targeting capabilities of digital. And we're quickly evolving the advertising industry to simultaneously benefit our advertisers as well as improve our overall consumer experience, and we don't see these goals as being mutually exclusive. Frankly, what we're trying to do is combine the best of both TV and digital, uniting scale and targeting a top-tier -- with top-tier content. That's one of the reasons why we're very bullish about the Upfront. In terms of our own new products, we've discussed before that we have built on the Turner Data Cloud, which is the central repository of all of our consumer information. And that's helping us launch new innovative products that focus on analytics, targeting an ROI. So just the names of the products, or some of them, we've got individual products called Targeting Now, Audience Now, ROI Now, Provable ROI, and what all that means is that it's going to be targeting audience-based selling coupled with our data cloud and client insights. And I think there are going to be increasing opportunities over time, and that's going to be a major, major focus in our Upfronts. And then I think you asked specifically with respect to OTT. I think the opportunities to develop advanced targeting capabilities in OTT are absolutely there. They're available. That is what -- assuming that the OTT offering is, in fact, ad-supported, FilmStruck, which is our first domestic offering, is going to be non-ad-supported, which is consistent with Turner Classic Movies. So I think the targeting opportunities will only grow over time, and we're still very, very -- in the very early stages. So we believe that TV advertising has to evolve, but it's going to remain the most effective option for brand advertisers to convey their message at scale. And that's why we expect a resurgence in TV advertising beginning at this year's Upfront.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we had a question -- there were several points. The Hulu question, Jessica, what was it?
componenttext: So we had a question -- there were several points. The Hulu question, Jessica, what was it?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, sorry. I mean, obviously, Hulu announced this week, and it can potentially be a really compelling product. And I was just wondering if you envision yourself participating in Hulu and the Hulu over-the-top service.
componenttext: Oh, sorry. I mean, obviously, Hulu announced this week, and it can potentially be a really compelling product. And I was just wondering if you envision yourself participating in Hulu and the Hulu over-the-top service.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I see. Okay. Let me start. Let me say -- and John, you may want to fill in. If you just -- maybe, maybe we want our networks in every one of these packets. I mean, I think we ought to include that in a larger view of how the industry is evolving. And
componenttext: Oh, I see. Okay. Let me start. Let me say -- and John, you may want to fill in. If you just -- maybe, maybe we want our networks in every one of these packets. I mean, I think we ought to include that in a larger view of how the industry is evolving. And if you think about subscription VOD, it's been an opportunity that started with the first SVOD service, which is called HBO, a long time ago. And what we're watching happen, and I think it probably did start with HBO a decade ago, is consumers want to expect they're going to demand SVOD access to all their favorite networks, all their favorite shows. And what we've been seeing as an evolution is that on-demand functionality and better guides are sprouting up, first in HBO, then at some of the broadband-delivered services. And increasingly, you're seeing more full on-demand offerings of current exhibition networks and better interfaces guides and recommendation engines at places like Comcast, Verizon, Sling has one. And for us, with our networks, whether it's the Turner networks or the HBO networks, we've long said that we'd like our networks and their programming, including the debuts of current first-season exhibitions like what John is talking about and what Richard has been doing for years at HBO. We want them to be on-demand, and we would like to see most of our networks, whichever exhibition window, first run or syndication to be on-demand. And we're basically in an enviable position that our networks, Turner and HBO, are among the most desired networks for consumers and, therefore, to be included in all these packages. So you'll hear, I think, increasingly, of different packages with different network offerings that consumers can choose between at different price points available from existing cable, satellite and telco distributors, increasingly from new virtual distributors, whether it be Hulu, whether it's Amazon, Apple, whoever comes in and creates packages for consumers. So I think what you're seeing is a very vibrant rebirth of the strength of TV networks and TV programming across all of these distribution platforms. And because of our -- we've always taken the position being the first to launch VOD that we think more of it is better for consumers. And therefore, we're going to try to be available in all the packages consumers are interested in.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as it relates to DreamWorks Animation transaction, I don't think you're going to see significantly more consolidation. That being said, the business is getting more and more stratified. Big franchises are worth -- are more valuable than ever. But I do
componenttext: And as it relates to DreamWorks Animation transaction, I don't think you're going to see significantly more consolidation. That being said, the business is getting more and more stratified. Big franchises are worth -- are more valuable than ever. But I don't think there's a lot of those that are actually available at this point in time. And so I don't think that, that's going to be kind of a precursor to a lot of transactions.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I should add. I should have said it. Let's not limit the VOD transformation to the United States. You're seeing very strong SVOD proliferation all over the world. And whether it's the Warner $0.10 venture in China, whether it's some of our HBO o
componenttext: One thing I should add. I should have said it. Let's not limit the VOD transformation to the United States. You're seeing very strong SVOD proliferation all over the world. And whether it's the Warner $0.10 venture in China, whether it's some of our HBO overseas, VOD services; whether it's companies like Sky and others in the U.K.; and then South America, they're launching VOD; whether it's networks or programming, we're seeing our stuff going into all of these new platforms, and it's raising the value not only of our content if you think of it show by show but also of our networks.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, one last follow-up. But is it all television? Or do you think this is film-based as well?
componenttext: Jeff, one last follow-up. But is it all television? Or do you think this is film-based as well?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mean, SVOD exhibition of films? Because you certainly have had that for more than a decade on HBO.
componenttext: You mean, SVOD exhibition of films? Because you certainly have had that for more than a decade on HBO.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But not so much outside the U.S.
componenttext: But not so much outside the U.S.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, you do. Kevin, you can add. You've got film licensing SVOD all over the world.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, you do. Kevin, you can add. You've got film licensing SVOD all over the world.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think you're seeing it's a critical component of any SVOD offering that wants to be of scale, that you have to have movies and television.
componenttext: Yes. And I think you're seeing it's a critical component of any SVOD offering that wants to be of scale, that you have to have movies and television.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let's remember, and we've tried to make this point over and over, the SVOD exhibition or the VOD exhibition, it's not just on a -- what you think of as an SVOD service, it's also in what used to be thought of as traditional TV services that becom
componenttext: Yes. And let's remember, and we've tried to make this point over and over, the SVOD exhibition or the VOD exhibition, it's not just on a -- what you think of as an SVOD service, it's also in what used to be thought of as traditional TV services that become on-demand services.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two Turner-related questions. First, on the affiliate fee growth, several of your peers see impact from the distributor consideration and some rate resets dragging on their growth. Obviously, you're putting up great growth right now. Do you expect to have
componenttext: Two Turner-related questions. First, on the affiliate fee growth, several of your peers see impact from the distributor consideration and some rate resets dragging on their growth. Obviously, you're putting up great growth right now. Do you expect to have any impact in the future from consolidation? Is any impact of consolidation already in your results, or perhaps the way you're structured, you won't be impacted by that? And then my second question is on ELEAGUE. Specifically, most strategies we see is taking linear content and finding new digital avenues. This is a case where you're taking something that's done well digitally and you're bringing it to TV. Could you just talk a little bit about what -- why you think that's the right strategy, what your hopes are for that product?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Mike. Look, with respect to our affiliate fees, I think you have the forecast or the guidance that we provided for this year and next year where we expect domestic subscriber revenues to be in the low teens. I think it's fair to say that, th
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Mike. Look, with respect to our affiliate fees, I think you have the forecast or the guidance that we provided for this year and next year where we expect domestic subscriber revenues to be in the low teens. I think it's fair to say that, that considers the current environment, the number of distributors and what's happening in the marketplace. And when you have a highly concentrated portfolio of must-have networks, which we do, where we've got 85% of our affiliate revenues in 4 networks, I think it's a really advantageous place to be. So I think I'll leave it at that because obviously, we're not going to specifically comment on any particular consolidation. And then with respect to ELEAGUE, look, this is one of the innovations with respect to content that I think we're particularly excited about and proud of. And it's really -- it's not necessarily by design that we're looking to take digital content and move it to the TV. It's more just really trying to position the company to be where consumers are. And looking at secular growth areas and in looking at areas where particularly young people are spending tremendous amounts of time, you obviously have to pay attention to the gaming industry, but this whole notion of very significant population of individuals who are really excited to sit and watch professional gamers and some of the best gamers in the world, that's already happening. It's happening globally. And in some countries, it represents some of the highest levels of consumption of video content. So in some respects, having ELEAGUE be aired on TBS is somewhat of an experiment. I think we're going to learn a lot this year. And I look forward to hopefully building a big franchise and a big asset along with our partners on both TV and digital platforms.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your line (sic) [ question ] comes from Vasily Karasyov from CLCA (sic) [ CLSA ].
componenttext: Your line (sic) [ question ] comes from Vasily Karasyov from CLCA (sic) [ CLSA ].

componenttext: John, I have a couple of quick ones for you on Turner. I think in Jeff's remarks, he said that sports was up in advertising and news. Can you tell us what the advertising for entertainment at TBS ex sports is with Turner? And also, my question is, you spoke in answering Alexia's question about what went right at Turner. Is there anything that you think will be changing in the next TV seasons, how you approach things?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. Let me start with the last part. I mean, listen, I think, to be completed candid, not everything goes right in any of our business.
componenttext: Terrific. Let me start with the last part. I mean, listen, I think, to be completed candid, not everything goes right in any of our business.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wait, really?
componenttext: Wait, really?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I have to say we are off to a terrific start. And at this moment, I can't think of a thing that if we were to look backwards that we would do differently. And really excited about looking forward. I think you should expect us not only to continue to p
componenttext: But I have to say we are off to a terrific start. And at this moment, I can't think of a thing that if we were to look backwards that we would do differently. And really excited about looking forward. I think you should expect us not only to continue to produce high-quality compelling programming but to try to rebrand these networks into -- continue to be must-have distinctive destinations for original programming, acquired programming and sports. And so I couldn't be more proud of the team under David and Kevin's direction and where we stand today and where we're going. So simple answer is really pleased; wouldn't really want to change a thing.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of advertising...
componenttext: In terms of advertising...

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And advertising and ratings for entertainment ex sports and news?
componenttext: And advertising and ratings for entertainment ex sports and news?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I would say cost across the portfolio, most of the growth did come from both news and sports, which is why we have that diverse portfolio. Ratings on the entertainment networks, I think it's almost went down a bit, and the scatter pricing was not
componenttext: Yes. So I would say cost across the portfolio, most of the growth did come from both news and sports, which is why we have that diverse portfolio. Ratings on the entertainment networks, I think it's almost went down a bit, and the scatter pricing was not enough to offset that. But in aggregate, overall domestic entertainment advertising was fine.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Vijay Jayant from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Vijay Jayant from Evercore ISI.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a question for Richard. I just wanted to sort of understand as HBO NOW is a standalone product, trying to be an all-encompassing product for a consumer. Is there an optimal amount of content you expect in terms of new originals every year split betwe
componenttext: It's a question for Richard. I just wanted to sort of understand as HBO NOW is a standalone product, trying to be an all-encompassing product for a consumer. Is there an optimal amount of content you expect in terms of new originals every year split between comedies, dramas, kids, and as you go international, how much local content do you need to make that a viable successful product rather? And where are we on that transition there as one?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of how we aggregate our programming decisions, I think as you look at the network right now, you see kind of a textbook example of how we break up different genres: documentaries, miniseries, half hours, hours, original films, sports programming.
componenttext: In terms of how we aggregate our programming decisions, I think as you look at the network right now, you see kind of a textbook example of how we break up different genres: documentaries, miniseries, half hours, hours, original films, sports programming. And as I've said before, the mission of programming is to build as many addicts as we can out there in the consumer base, and different people love different things. So you have huge Silicon Valley fans, huge John Oliver or Bill Maher fans, huge sports fans. So we like the way we're breaking up our choices. And a lot of this, of course, is informed by the talent that comes through the door. Somebody comes in with a brilliant idea for an additional half hour. We're not going to say no to it because we have a certain number that we think is a ceiling. That's not how we make choices. In terms of HBO NOW, what we have done is we've augmented our programming with decisions like Jon Stewart and VICE News, and I think Bill Simmons will work across all platforms. So again, that opportunity to not be constrained by schedule is opening up a lot of creativity on the part of our talent who are coming in literally every week with new ideas. So you're going to see more and more of that going forward. So listen, we like our mix. We think if you'll look at just the Emmy nominations and the Emmy wins of last year, I think the thing that was most rewarding for us was that they were across all categories, a wide range of categories. And I think that's what makes our programming mix so special.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can try my luck, any update on HBO NOW subscriber numbers?
componenttext: If I can try my luck, any update on HBO NOW subscriber numbers?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get into numbers other than to say that we've had a good start with sub growth this year, both in terms of the traditional ecosystem and NOW, and we're very encouraged by what we're seeing. And as we learn more and more about our subscrib
componenttext: I'm not going to get into numbers other than to say that we've had a good start with sub growth this year, both in terms of the traditional ecosystem and NOW, and we're very encouraged by what we're seeing. And as we learn more and more about our subscribers and our marketing becomes more precise, particularly with NOW, I think we're going to do even better.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente from Nomura.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente from Nomura.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question for Howard. Howard, the company had a really strong quarter across the board, beating Street estimates by a lot. But just on the outlook, you didn't raise the outlook. So totally hear you on the 2Q items you mentioned in your prepared re
componenttext: Just one question for Howard. Howard, the company had a really strong quarter across the board, beating Street estimates by a lot. But just on the outlook, you didn't raise the outlook. So totally hear you on the 2Q items you mentioned in your prepared remarks. But is this just a little bit of conservatism? Or has the visibility around the rest of your expectations changed at all as you look segment by segment?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had a terrific first quarter, again, with a double-digit ROI and a 25% EPS growth. We are really pleased with how we're executing, and we see that continuing across our businesses. But look, it's still early in the year. We did mention, and you just me
componenttext: We had a terrific first quarter, again, with a double-digit ROI and a 25% EPS growth. We are really pleased with how we're executing, and we see that continuing across our businesses. But look, it's still early in the year. We did mention, and you just mentioned back, the fact that we are making some investments across the business. And look, we're also mindful that FX can move around. So at this point, we're still comfortable with the $5.30 to $5.40, and we are on track, clearly, for that.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of John Janedis from Jefferies.
componenttext: Comes from the line of John Janedis from Jefferies.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, maybe a follow-up to your comment on SVOD and related distributors or offerings. From your perspective, how do you think about the potential for them to expand or stabilize the pay TV universe relative to the declines over the past 18 months or so?
componenttext: Jeff, maybe a follow-up to your comment on SVOD and related distributors or offerings. From your perspective, how do you think about the potential for them to expand or stabilize the pay TV universe relative to the declines over the past 18 months or so? Or maybe asked differently, do you have any line of sight or confidence in improved subtrends as a result of new entrants or offerings?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's important to look, basically, to be aggregate, the performance in the cable telco satellite world. So you do have affiliates, cable affiliates who are growing subs in penetration. And the reason basically is they are offering very effect
componenttext: Yes. I think it's important to look, basically, to be aggregate, the performance in the cable telco satellite world. So you do have affiliates, cable affiliates who are growing subs in penetration. And the reason basically is they are offering very effective packages of VOD. They've got various packages at different prices with different network bundles for consumers. They've got good guide interfaces. And so you have a fairly large disparity in performance between distributors. And I think if you look at the high performance, you see where the future can go. And the fact that you now have more VOD offerings and different packages and price points is basically, I think -- and it -- we've seen it happen, it's going to increase penetration because consumers are going to find more packages that suit what they want. And in most cases, that'll be the biggest and largest packages of the big networks. But not in all cases. And so I think you're going to see -- and remember, to the extent you have some marketing of VOD products -- think of broadband delivery with good navigation, it basically increases consumer demand -- consumer recognition for powerful networks like CNN, TNT, HBO. All of that has kind of a national effect of increasing the presence of TV networks because all age groups increasingly now are finding their favorite programs offered the way they want them. They find a way to the networks if we sell them in the right distribution offering.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just add one thing? There's too many networks in the United States, and we've been saying for years that there's going to be a rationalization of those networks. So as you think about subscription trends going forward, I think there are going to be
componenttext: Can I just add one thing? There's too many networks in the United States, and we've been saying for years that there's going to be a rationalization of those networks. So as you think about subscription trends going forward, I think there are going to be increasingly differentiated subscription trends. Meaning that marginal or lesser value networks are going to find it very difficult to keep their footing and keep pace with the best networks. And I think, further to what Jeff just said, as affiliates, whether they're traditional or nontraditional affiliates, put out packages, smaller packages of better networks at lower economic price points, we're going to be able to attract back households into the multichannel ecosystem that have, frankly, moved away because they don't see the value of the uber-bundles. That'll be good for us.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe separately, just back to HBO for a second. Now with Game of Thrones premiering a week or 2 ago, can you talk about your confidence in the slate's ramping and accelerating subscriber growth the rest of the year, and to what extent maybe the
componenttext: And then maybe separately, just back to HBO for a second. Now with Game of Thrones premiering a week or 2 ago, can you talk about your confidence in the slate's ramping and accelerating subscriber growth the rest of the year, and to what extent maybe the programming budget is locked in or may need to move higher? And now that HBO NOW, that you're a year in, can you share some data on how the subs are different from traditional linear subs from either maybe a churn or engagement perspective?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The second first. Obviously, it's a younger demo. It's about a decade younger than our traditional HBO sub. In terms of the programming slate, look, we're very excited about what's coming, Vice Principals with Danny McBride, Sarah Jessica Parker's D
componenttext: Sure. The second first. Obviously, it's a younger demo. It's about a decade younger than our traditional HBO sub. In terms of the programming slate, look, we're very excited about what's coming, Vice Principals with Danny McBride, Sarah Jessica Parker's Divorce, our co-production with Warner Bros., Westworld, just an extraordinary varied and dynamic slate of stuff coming. And Game of Thrones also has a couple of years left as well before they finish out their story.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, do HBO Now subs churn more? Or is it negligible?
componenttext: Richard, do HBO Now subs churn more? Or is it negligible?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, as we saw on the Nordics, churn was a bit validated initially. But as you would expect, the churn has been coming down as our subscriber base has aged. I think as we continue to drive churn down over time, we improve the service, we improve ou
componenttext: Well, look, as we saw on the Nordics, churn was a bit validated initially. But as you would expect, the churn has been coming down as our subscriber base has aged. I think as we continue to drive churn down over time, we improve the service, we improve our UI and UX. We roll out more of the programming that I spoke of earlier. I think we'll learn, and we are learning, how to better serve our customer and continue to affect a decline in churn.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Bryan Kraft from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Bryan Kraft from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question for Richard and for John. Richard, just a question on HBO, following up on John's question. How do you gauge what is a successful show on HBO versus an unsuccessful one? Is there a minimum audience level that you're looking for? And then
componenttext: I had a question for Richard and for John. Richard, just a question on HBO, following up on John's question. How do you gauge what is a successful show on HBO versus an unsuccessful one? Is there a minimum audience level that you're looking for? And then for John, John, just curious, how is the reduction in ad loads at truTV going to impact pricing and audience levels for advertising on the network? Do you see the increase in CPMs and ratings offsetting the reduction in ad loads?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your question of how we gauge a successful show, look, it's largely about whether we think something is elevating the brand. And that's obviously a subjective judgment that we make all the time. It's not so much about rating as whether or not it's serv
componenttext: On your question of how we gauge a successful show, look, it's largely about whether we think something is elevating the brand. And that's obviously a subjective judgment that we make all the time. It's not so much about rating as whether or not it's serving what we think is its design purpose to affect resonance with a particular part of our consumer base. So as I said earlier, it's all about developing a kind of engagement with our subscriber. Some people are going to look at Real Sports with the same degree of passion that other people look at Bill Maher or John Oliver. Some people are going to look at Veep with the same passion that other people will look at Silicon Valley. So this is a very subjective determination. We've been doing it for a long time. We think we have pretty good instincts about how to build a large variety in our slate, which appeals to a huge part of our consumer base. There's no exact science to it, and obviously, critical acclaim plays a role. But we have a very good collective instinct inside the company when we think something is resonating with a particular part of our audience. And we give our creative teams an opportunity to stay with it and develop story and continue to build the show as we've shown over many years.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. It's John. With respect -- for anybody who's unaware because you made reference to truTV and ad loads, we had announced, a number of months ago, our intention that beginning in the fourth quarter of this year, we're going to essentially take the n
componenttext: Thanks. It's John. With respect -- for anybody who's unaware because you made reference to truTV and ad loads, we had announced, a number of months ago, our intention that beginning in the fourth quarter of this year, we're going to essentially take the number of minutes per hour on truTV dedicated to advertising. We're going to essentially cut it in half. And that, again, is consistent with our desire to evolve the industry that's going to simultaneously benefit our advertisers and improve the overall consumer experience. I will tell you, we are not doing it to lose money. So we fully intend to provide increased value per inventory unit that we sell. And now it's up to us to demonstrate that. But we are actively going to be moving beyond the 32nd spot of business to create innovative new ad products for our advertisers and marketers. And we made a number of announcements a number of months ago at CES, including data plus with longer-form brand ad breaks and launchpad, which is a social tool; and Courageous, which is our own in-house ability to develop branded content in the form of advertising. Again, I would say we're going to learn a lot, but we absolutely believe that this experiment is not going to result in us taking a step back.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to see if I could follow up on that. I mean, John, how are you thinking about the ad loads on the other networks? I mean, do you first do this with truTV, see what you learn, and then start thinking about the larger networks? Or is there anyth
componenttext: I just want to see if I could follow up on that. I mean, John, how are you thinking about the ad loads on the other networks? I mean, do you first do this with truTV, see what you learn, and then start thinking about the larger networks? Or is there anything that you're doing now in terms of ad load reductions on TBS and TNT?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not doing anything material today. And one of the reasons why we are starting with this commitment on truTV is, obviously, it's a network where we have less advertising exposure than some of our larger networks like TBS and TNT. Having said that, th
componenttext: We're not doing anything material today. And one of the reasons why we are starting with this commitment on truTV is, obviously, it's a network where we have less advertising exposure than some of our larger networks like TBS and TNT. Having said that, the type of approach and ideology that we're -- we have with truTV, which we think will succeed, we're already beginning to plan for on some of our other networks. And I believe it was Kevin Reilly at TCA that mentioned that on some of our new original programming, we're actually going to be making more minutes of content with the expectation that on a number of those new original scripted series, we'll probably be running fewer ad commercial breaks. So this is going to be an evolution. But it's something that we're planning now for what's going to take place in the future.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to thank everyone for hanging in through our medical section. And I hope you can all see how we're so excited about not only our prospects for the business this year but in the years out beyond that. We think the company is very well positione
componenttext: I just want to thank everyone for hanging in through our medical section. And I hope you can all see how we're so excited about not only our prospects for the business this year but in the years out beyond that. We think the company is very well positioned and the evolution of the networks at Warner's going global is proceeding as well as I could have hoped. And I'm also seeing a lot of encouragement in industry developments. I think the industry around the world is finally starting to catch up to the innovation speed necessary to take this huge value that's resident in all the network offerings, not just ours, and bring it to consumers in a way that consumers increasingly want. So we're quite encouraged about the environment that we're operating in and particularly, our strength relative to the others.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everybody. Have a great day.
componenttext: Thanks, everybody. Have a great day.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Time Warner Inc. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Mike, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I will now turn the call over to Michael Kopelman,
componenttext:
Welcome to the Time Warner Inc. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Mike, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I will now turn the call over to Michael Kopelman, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Kopelman, you may begin.
